channel.title: SSL cracked
channel.description:
i know this is a bit old but i studied it in col last week. SSL which is used to secure web pages like online banking, paypal, and other secure sites now may be at risk. a bunch of uni hackers have managed to crack SSL using 200 ps3's and some computers here is some info i pulled up with a quick google search. Take a look, if you want more just google it. Looks like it will be atleest 6 months before anyone can replicate it but never the less make sure you pay attention on sites from now on.
http://www.engadget.com/2008/12/30/hackers-playstation-3-make-ssl-much-less-secure/ http://hackaday.com/2008/12/30/25c3-hackers-completely-break-ssl-using-200-ps3s/ http://www.google.co.uk/search?hl=en&safe=off&q=SSL+cracked+200+ps3&btnG=Search&meta=

item.title: SSL cracked
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yeah… SSL was NOT cracked. This just demonstrated that MD5 sucks, which we all knew already.

Read full topic

item.title: SSL cracked
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

It was due to a weakness in a certificate issuers order system (related to MD5), which has since been fixed.

Read full topic

item.description:

Rofl.

Quite impressive.[/quote]

LMAO, i missed that xD

item.title: SSL cracked
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

N00b1:

crack SSL using 200 ps3’s

1600 cores of hacking! Why does it need so much computing power? I suprised it took this long for people to crack SSL.

Read full topic

PlayStation 3 used to hack SSL, Xbox used to play Boogie Bunnies

Between the juvenile delinquent hordes of PlayStation Home and some lackluster holiday figures, the PlayStation has been sort of a bummer lately, for reasons t...


Hackaday – 30 Dec 08

25C3: Hackers completely break SSL using 200 PS3s

A team of security researchers and academics has broken a core piece of internet technology. They made their work public at the 25th Chaos Communication Congress in Berlin today. The team was able …
